Anna Lorimer

Hi! I'm a second year Combinatorics and Optimization Major/Computer Science Minor at the University of Waterloo with a passion for Software Engineering.

What is Combinatorics and Optimization?

Fun Facts:

• I can make macarons

• I have my Level 1 Parelli certification

• My favourite movie is Pacific Rim

More

How did I get started in Software Engineering?

Early on I figured out that if I treated whatever I was doing as an experiment, I got support at home and left alone enough to test stuff out and try a lot of new things. This led to some really weird food combinations and strange things that I made out of paper and whatever else I could find. I pretty much l iked to mess around with anything I could get my hands on. This included the top-notch (at the time) Dell PC my parents bought when I was 9. So like in many families I became the go-to person for all things to do with the computer, especially since I was the only kid. One summer I did attend an HTML/CSS coding camp for girls at the local university and I enjoyed it and working with the other girls, but there weren’t really other opportunities around then to follow up afterwards. So I did lots of other things. Writing (in English & French), storyboards, film making, baking and training horses. What I really enjoyed about all these things were the different ways of thinking and problem solving that were involved with these activities. In the case of the large animals (horses) I had to give quite a bit of thought to thinking about things from their perspective, not just my own. I didn’t think of of this as “pre-engineering or CS” but the components and passion for problem solving were there in these activities. Teaching a 1500-pound horse to stand on a pedestal like a circus elephant takes a surprising amount of problem solving and critical thinking skills, not to mention perseverance.

Although my high school had computer science classes, it was all pretty low key and there were no girls involved, just boys who had known each other forever. My school was not a techie hub. Math, though, that is my thing. Thankfully, my love of math didn’t get squashed and I ended up in an undergraduate math program at the University of Waterloo determined to get into Combinatorics and Optimization to study cryptography. Since the computer science department is within the Math Faculty at Waterloo, all first year students are required to complete two computer science courses. Not going to lie, those courses were tough and I’m not certain that I would have continued in computer science if I hadn’t had a wonderfully supportive group of friends (both in CS and outside). Although I originally thought I would prefer to work on my own, I found I really thrived on the cooperative projects we did for class. Once I had completed those required courses, I knew I wanted to do more. Computer science provides me with that spectacular combination of theory and application. When I found out that I could combine my love of math and computer science, I was ecstatic. So here I am! I just started my second term of second year and I have never been more excited and motivated.
